file_metadata.authors: ["Sofia Maselli", "Sebastian Real", "Patrick McMillen", "Madeleine Oudin", "Michael Levin", "Maria Roque"]
file_metadata.title: The Yin and Yang of Breast Cancer: Ion Channels as Determinants of Left–Right Functional Differences

chunks.text: Breast cancer exhibits heterogeneity in molecular subtypes and clinical outcomes, with tumor location potentially influencing behavior. Previous research identified differential methylation and membrane potential between left (L) and right (R) breast tumors. This study investigates the ion channels responsible for this phenomenon and associated phenotypic features in mice, human samples, and public datasets.
chunks.chunk_summary: This study investigates the role of ion channels in left-right differences in breast tumor biology.
chunks.authors: ["Sofia Maselli", "Sebastian Real", "Patrick McMillen", "Madeleine Oudin", "Michael Levin", "Maria Roque"]

chunks.text: L-sided tumors exhibit a more depolarized state than R-sided tumors. A 6-ion channel gene signature (CACNA1C, CACNA2D2, CACNB2, KCNJ11, SCN3A, SCN3B) is associated with tumor laterality, with lower expression in L-tumors. In silico analysis reveals an inverse correlation between the signature and DNA methylation writers, cancer progression processes (proliferation, stemness), and patient survival. In vivo mouse models confirm increased KI67 and CD44 markers in L-sided tumors, with a similar trend observed in human L-tumors.
chunks.topic: Ion channel signature and tumor characteristics
chunks.chunk_summary: A 6-ion channel gene signature is associated with tumor laterality, depolarization, proliferation, stemness, and survival.
chunks.authors: ["Sofia Maselli", "Sebastian Real", "Patrick McMillen", "Madeleine Oudin", "Michael Levin", "Maria Roque"]

chunks.text: This study provides insights into the impact of anatomical location on breast cancer biology and highlights the need for further research into potential differential treatment options.
chunks.chunk_summary: The findings suggest the need for further research into location-specific breast cancer treatments.
chunks.authors: ["Sofia Maselli", "Sebastian Real", "Patrick McMillen", "Madeleine Oudin", "Michael Levin", "Maria Roque"]

chunks.text: Ion channels (ICH) regulate ion flow across cell membranes, influencing membrane potential, signaling, and gene expression in all cells, not just neurons. Bioelectric communication, using conserved molecular components, is crucial for morphogenesis. ICH dysregulation, leading to altered membrane potential and signaling, can promote tumorigenesis and therapy resistance. Cancer can be viewed as a disorder of informational boundaries between cells, with bioelectric disruptions triggering cancerous behavior even without DNA damage. This perspective has led to effective cancer treatments in amphibians and is being tested in human tissues.
chunks.topic: Role of ion channels in cancer
chunks.chunk_summary: Ion channel dysregulation disrupts bioelectric communication, contributing to cancer development.
chunks.authors: ["Sofia Maselli", "Sebastian Real", "Patrick McMillen", "Madeleine Oudin", "Michael Levin", "Maria Roque"]

chunks.text: ICH participate in tumor microenvironment (TME) and cancer cell crosstalk, influencing tumor development and therapy resistance. Cancer cells' ICH respond to TME changes, while TME components' ICH modulate their function and cytokine/growth factor secretion. Targeting ICH involved in TME-tumor interaction may offer new anticancer therapy opportunities.
chunks.chunk_summary: Ion channels mediate interactions between the tumor microenvironment and cancer cells, influencing tumor development and treatment response.
chunks.authors: ["Sofia Maselli", "Sebastian Real", "Patrick McMillen", "Madeleine Oudin", "Michael Levin", "Maria Roque"]

chunks.text: Breast cancer (BC) exhibits heterogeneity, including tumor laterality. While breast tumors are generally considered similar regardless of side, studies suggest differences in surrounding tissue. Mammary glands are not identical, with variations in structure. Paired organs, including breasts, show physiological and molecular differences. These normal differences can impact tumor biology differently on each side.
chunks.chunk_summary: Normal left-right differences in mammary glands may influence tumor biology in a side-specific manner.
chunks.authors: ["Sofia Maselli", "Sebastian Real", "Patrick McMillen", "Madeleine Oudin", "Michael Levin", "Maria Roque"]

chunks.text: Left-sided BC incidence is slightly higher, though the reasons are unclear. Similar lateral differences in cancer incidence and progression exist in other paired organs. While these differences were thought to have minimal clinical impact, growing evidence suggests their importance. Studies show distinct gene expression profiles in L-R tumors in mice and differential responses to therapies in humans based on TME. L-sided BC has been linked to more aggressive biology and worse outcomes. Understanding these differences is crucial for diagnosis and treatment.
chunks.chunk_summary: Emerging evidence suggests that left-right differences in breast tumors have clinical significance, impacting tumor biology and treatment response.
chunks.authors: ["Sofia Maselli", "Sebastian Real", "Patrick McMillen", "Madeleine Oudin", "Michael Levin", "Maria Roque"]

chunks.text: Previous research revealed distinct methylation profiles and membrane potential differences between L-R breast tumors. Given the known bioelectricity's role in tumorigenesis and gene expression differences in normal L-R breast tissues, this study investigates the ICH involved in these differences and their impact on tumor cell characteristics, aiming to uncover novel therapeutic targets.
chunks.chunk_summary: This study aims to identify the ion channels responsible for left-right differences in breast tumors and their impact on tumor characteristics.
chunks.authors: ["Sofia Maselli", "Sebastian Real", "Patrick McMillen", "Madeleine Oudin", "Michael Levin", "Maria Roque"]

chunks.text: Using the MMTV-PyMT mouse model, which spontaneously develops L-R mammary tumors, researchers investigated laterality's role in tumor bioelectric properties. Paired L-R tumors from the 4th gland were analyzed using fluorescent probes with opposite charges to measure the bioelectric state (MT/DB ratio). Confocal microscopy revealed a decreased MT/DB ratio in L-sided tumors, suggesting a more depolarized state.
chunks.topic: Bioelectric state of left-right tumors in mice
chunks.chunk_summary: Left-sided tumors in mice showed a more depolarized state than right-sided tumors.
chunks.authors: ["Sofia Maselli", "Sebastian Real", "Patrick McMillen", "Madeleine Oudin", "Michael Levin", "Maria Roque"]

chunks.text: Flow cytometry analysis of samples from 3/5 mice confirmed the decreased MT/DB ratio in L-sided tumors, consistent with microscopy results. This further supports the observation of a more depolarized state in L-sided tumors compared to R-sided tumors.
chunks.chunk_summary: Flow cytometry confirmed the more depolarized state of left-sided tumors in mice.
chunks.authors: ["Sofia Maselli", "Sebastian Real", "Patrick McMillen", "Madeleine Oudin", "Michael Levin", "Maria Roque"]

chunks.text: A bioinformatic approach was used to identify ICH genes involved in L-R bioelectric differences. Human ICH genes (330) were obtained from the HGNC database, and expression levels of 319 genes were downloaded from 781 invasive breast tumors (393 L-sided, 388 R-sided) in the TCGA dataset. Gene Set Enrichment Analysis (GSEA) identified four gene sets with significantly decreased expression in L-sided tumors: WP-ENERGY-METABOLISM, REACTOME-PHASE-0-RAPID-DEPOLARISATION, REACTOME_CARDIAC-CONDUCTION, and CANCER-MODULES. Combining these gene sets led to the identification of a 6-ICH signature (CACNA1C, CACNA2D2, CACNB2, KCNJ11, SCN3A, SCN3B) associated with tumor laterality.
chunks.chunk_summary: Bioinformatic analysis identified a 6-ICH signature associated with left-right differences in breast tumors.
chunks.authors: ["Sofia Maselli", "Sebastian Real", "Patrick McMillen", "Madeleine Oudin", "Michael Levin", "Maria Roque"]

chunks.text: The Human Protein Atlas confirmed protein-level detection of the six channels in normal breast tissue. Analysis of the 6-ICH signature expression in normal vs. tumor tissues and L- vs. R-sided tumors using the Xena Functional Genomics Explorer showed decreased expression in tumor cells compared to normal tissue and in L-sided compared to R-sided tumors. Adding or removing genes from the signature affected the association with laterality, supporting the robustness of the 6-ICH signature.
chunks.chunk_summary: The 6-ICH signature showed decreased expression in tumor cells and left-sided tumors, validating its association with tumor laterality.
chunks.authors: ["Sofia Maselli", "Sebastian Real", "Patrick McMillen", "Madeleine Oudin", "Michael Levin", "Maria Roque"]

chunks.text: To investigate the phenotypic impact of the 6-ICH signature, expression data was dichotomized into High and Low groups, and differential gene expression (DGE) analysis was performed. The Low-expressing group showed upregulation of mitotic genes and downregulation of membrane potential regulating processes, suggesting increased mitotic activity in L-sided tumors with low 6-ICH expression.
chunks.chunk_summary: Low 6-ICH expression is associated with increased mitotic activity and decreased membrane potential regulation.
chunks.authors: ["Sofia Maselli", "Sebastian Real", "Patrick McMillen", "Madeleine Oudin", "Michael Levin", "Maria Roque"]

chunks.text: Analysis of the correlation between the 6-ICH signature and KI67 (proliferation marker) and stemness scores in Discovery and Validation cohorts of primary breast tumors revealed a strong inverse correlation. ROC analyses demonstrated the signature's ability to distinguish between high and low expression of KI67 and stemness scores. These correlations were confirmed in a pan-cancer analysis.
chunks.chunk_summary: The 6-ICH signature inversely correlates with proliferation and stemness markers in breast cancer and pan-cancer analyses.
chunks.authors: ["Sofia Maselli", "Sebastian Real", "Patrick McMillen", "Madeleine Oudin", "Michael Levin", "Maria Roque"]

chunks.text: Five-year survival rates (overall, disease-specific, disease-free, progression-free) were increased in high-expressing tumors compared to low-expressing tumors in both BC and pan-cancer patients.  A strong inverse correlation was found between the 6-ICH signature and a signature of DNA methylation writers (DNMT1, DNMT3A, DNMT3B, DNMT3L, TRDMT1, DMAP1). These results suggest the bioelectric signature's association with tumor laterality, cancer hallmarks (proliferation, stemness), DNA methylation regulators, and patient survival.
chunks.chunk_summary: High 6-ICH expression is associated with increased survival rates and inversely correlates with DNA methylation writers.
chunks.authors: ["Sofia Maselli", "Sebastian Real", "Patrick McMillen", "Madeleine Oudin", "Michael Levin", "Maria Roque"]

chunks.text: In vivo analysis of paired L-R tumors from four female mice confirmed the inverse correlation between the 6-ICH signature and proliferation (KI67) and stemness (CD44) markers. L-sided tumors showed significantly increased expression of both markers. A similar trend, though not statistically significant, was observed in human breast tumor RNA samples, with increased mean expression of KI67 and CD44 in L-sided tumors. These findings suggest that L-R breast tumors differ in proliferation and stemness, potentially influenced by differential ICH expression.
chunks.topic: In vivo validation of proliferation and stemness differences
chunks.chunk_summary: In vivo studies confirmed increased proliferation and stemness markers in left-sided tumors, supporting the link between the 6-ICH signature and these cancer hallmarks.
chunks.authors: ["Sofia Maselli", "Sebastian Real", "Patrick McMillen", "Madeleine Oudin", "Michael Levin", "Maria Roque"]

chunks.text: Breast cancer is a heterogeneous disease with diverse molecular subtypes and clinical outcomes. The relationship between tumor location and biological behavior remains an open question. Studies across species have shown L-R differences in paired organs, including gene expression profiles, embryonic development, and metabolic differences.  L-sided breast tumors are more frequent, but the causes are unclear. Previous research identified differential DNA methylation profiles and membrane potential differences between L-R breast tumors, suggesting that different L-R environments generate methylation differences leading to distinct bioelectric states. This study aimed to address L-R asymmetry at the organism level in mice and humans, showing that L-sided tumors exhibit a more depolarized state, increased proliferation and stemness markers, and lower ICH signature expression associated with reduced survival rates.
chunks.chunk_summary: Left-sided breast tumors exhibit distinct bioelectric states, increased proliferation and stemness markers, and lower ICH signature expression associated with reduced survival.
chunks.authors: ["Sofia Maselli", "Sebastian Real", "Patrick McMillen", "Madeleine Oudin", "Michael Levin", "Maria Roque"]

chunks.text: The microenvironments of L and R sides create a consistent difference in the bioelectric state of tumor cells, impacting tumor behavior. This study provides the first conclusive findings differentiating breast tumors based on bioelectric state, proliferation, and survival rate, according to their side.  A recent publication supports these findings, showing that L-sided BC is associated with more aggressive biology and worse outcomes.
chunks.topic: Impact of microenvironment on tumor behavior
chunks.chunk_summary: The study's findings highlight the impact of left-right microenvironments on tumor bioelectric state and behavior, with left-sided tumors showing more aggressive characteristics.
chunks.authors: ["Sofia Maselli", "Sebastian Real", "Patrick McMillen", "Madeleine Oudin", "Michael Levin", "Maria Roque"]

chunks.text: The 6-ICH signature associated with tumor side consists of calcium, sodium, and potassium channels. CACNA1C, CACNA2D2, and CACNB2 are subunits of voltage-gated calcium channels involved in various physiological processes. KCNJ11 codes for a potassium channel regulating insulin secretion and has been proposed as a metastasis regulator in triple-negative breast cancer. SCN3A and SCN3B are subunits of voltage-gated sodium channels important for action potential propagation. Recent findings highlight the clinical importance of sodium channels and the ionic microenvironment of breast tumors.  Predicting the outcome of gene expression shifts in these ICH is complex and context-dependent. The 6-ICH signature's impact on membrane potential is influenced by the collective actions of ion channels and transporters. Lower signature expression correlates with more depolarized membrane potential, potentially due to reduced function of voltage-independent potassium channels like KCNJ11, triggering activation of voltage-gated calcium and sodium channels and maintaining a depolarized state involved in cell cycle progression.
chunks.chunk_summary: The 6-ICH signature comprises ion channels with diverse functions, and its impact on membrane potential is complex and context-dependent, potentially influencing cell cycle progression.
chunks.authors: ["Sofia Maselli", "Sebastian Real", "Patrick McMillen", "Madeleine Oudin", "Michael Levin", "Maria Roque"]

chunks.text: Cancer cells tend to be more depolarized than normal counterparts. Fast-proliferating tumor cells exhibit depolarized membrane potential, while non- or less-proliferating cells are hyperpolarized. Depolarization is considered a signal for mitosis and DNA synthesis. Membrane potential also plays a role in stem cell differentiation, with hyperpolarization required for maturation and depolarization reducing the differentiated phenotype. Bioinformatic analyses showed that lower 6-ICH expression is associated with increased proliferation and stemness, and worse survival. Higher stemness indices are linked to increased cancer stem cells and a more de-differentiated phenotype, associated with worse prognosis and therapy resistance. Proliferation is crucial in BC evaluation, with KI67 as a key marker. The 6-ICH signature may modulate these processes by altering the bioelectric state in a side-dependent manner.
chunks.chunk_summary: Lower 6-ICH expression is associated with depolarization, increased proliferation and stemness, and worse survival, highlighting the signature's role in modulating these key cancer processes.
chunks.authors: ["Sofia Maselli", "Sebastian Real", "Patrick McMillen", "Madeleine Oudin", "Michael Levin", "Maria Roque"]

chunks.text: The tumor microenvironment (TME) plays a critical role in tumor development and therapy response. TME-derived factors can alter the epigenetic landscape of cancer cells, promoting tumorigenesis and therapy resistance through DNA methylation, histone modifications, and chromatin remodeling. TME components can also secrete exosomes and microvesicles that transfer epigenetic modifiers to cancer cells. The impact of TME on the tumor epigenome is significant because epigenetic changes are reversible and potentially targetable.
chunks.chunk_summary: The tumor microenvironment influences cancer cell epigenetics, contributing to tumorigenesis and therapy resistance.
chunks.authors: ["Sofia Maselli", "Sebastian Real", "Patrick McMillen", "Madeleine Oudin", "Michael Levin", "Maria Roque"]

chunks.text: Lipids play a crucial role in cellular membrane potential during cancer processes. Alterations in lipid metabolism and membrane composition affect membrane fluidity, ion channel activity, and signaling pathways. Lipid rafts organize membrane proteins involved in signaling and affect ion channel localization. Altered lipid metabolism can influence ion channel function and membrane potential, offering potential therapeutic interventions.
chunks.topic: Lipids and membrane potential in cancer
chunks.chunk_summary: Altered lipid metabolism in cancer cells can impact membrane potential and ion channel function, presenting potential therapeutic targets.
chunks.authors: ["Sofia Maselli", "Sebastian Real", "Patrick McMillen", "Madeleine Oudin", "Michael Levin", "Maria Roque"]

chunks.text: The link between L-R breast tumor differences and ICH suggests therapeutic opportunities using existing ICH-modulating drugs. Drug repositioning, repurposing existing drugs for new indications, is a promising approach for cancer treatment. An oncology-focused drug repurposing database lists 20 drugs targeting channels included in the 6-ICH signature. Repositioning these drugs could reduce development timelines and costs. The 6-ICH signature's inverse association with DNMT expression, but not other epigenetic modulators, suggests regulation by DNA methylation, warranting further investigation using DNMT inhibitors.
chunks.chunk_summary: The study's findings suggest potential therapeutic opportunities by repositioning existing ICH-modulating drugs, and further research is needed to investigate the relationship between the 6-ICH signature and DNA methylation.
chunks.authors: ["Sofia Maselli", "Sebastian Real", "Patrick McMillen", "Madeleine Oudin", "Michael Levin", "Maria Roque"]

chunks.text: This study suggests that anatomical location influences breast tumor bioelectric state, potentially mediated by ICH. The 6-ICH signature may modulate cancer progression processes, requiring further validation. The impact of anatomical location on BC biology and clinical outcomes warrants further investigation, suggesting potential differential treatment options with repurposed ICH drugs.
chunks.topic: Summary of findings and future directions
chunks.chunk_summary: Anatomical location influences breast tumor bioelectric state, and the 6-ICH signature may play a role in cancer progression, warranting further investigation into location-specific treatments.
chunks.authors: ["Sofia Maselli", "Sebastian Real", "Patrick McMillen", "Madeleine Oudin", "Michael Levin", "Maria Roque"]

chunks.text: RNA and tumor tissue from a patient tissue bank, with informed consent obtained according to the Declaration of Helsinki and approved by the Ethics Committee, were used. The study used MMTV-PyMT female mice housed under standard conditions. At 13 weeks, paired L-R breast tumors from the 4th gland were excised and processed for membrane potential measurement, DNA/RNA extraction.
chunks.chunk_summary: Human tumor samples from a tissue bank and mouse models were used in the study, with ethical approvals obtained.
chunks.authors: ["Sofia Maselli", "Sebastian Real", "Patrick McMillen", "Madeleine Oudin", "Michael Levin", "Maria Roque"]

chunks.text: Tumor cells were disaggregated using collagenase and hyaluronidase, filtered, and washed. Membrane potential was measured using DiBAC4(3) (DB) and MitoTracker Deep Red FM (MT) fluorescent probes. Fluorescence was measured by flow cytometry, and autofluorescence was subtracted. Data was analyzed using FlowJo software.
chunks.topic: Membrane potential measurement by flow cytometry
chunks.chunk_summary: Flow cytometry with fluorescent probes was used to measure membrane potential in disaggregated tumor cells.
chunks.authors: ["Sofia Maselli", "Sebastian Real", "Patrick McMillen", "Madeleine Oudin", "Michael Levin", "Maria Roque"]

chunks.text: Tumor slices were incubated with DB and MT in Fluorobrite DMEM. Images were captured using a confocal microscope, and a ratio of MT/DB integrated density was calculated and normalized to depolarized control images (treated with high KCl).
chunks.topic: Membrane potential measurement by confocal microscopy
chunks.chunk_summary: Confocal microscopy with fluorescent probes and KCl depolarization control was used to measure membrane potential in tumor slices.
chunks.authors: ["Sofia Maselli", "Sebastian Real", "Patrick McMillen", "Madeleine Oudin", "Michael Levin", "Maria Roque"]

chunks.text: RNA was extracted from mice tumors using a commercial kit and from human tumors using a Trizol-based protocol. cDNA was synthesized from purified RNA using M-MLV Reverse Transcriptase. Gene expression in mice tumors was analyzed by ddPCR using probes for KI67, CD44, and HPRT. Gene expression in human tumors was analyzed by qPCR using primers for CD44, KI67, and β-actin.
chunks.topic: RNA extraction and gene expression analysis
chunks.chunk_summary: RNA extraction, cDNA synthesis, and ddPCR/qPCR were used for gene expression analysis in mice and human tumors.
chunks.authors: ["Sofia Maselli", "Sebastian Real", "Patrick McMillen", "Madeleine Oudin", "Michael Levin", "Maria Roque"]

chunks.text: Human ICH genes were obtained from the HGNC database. Gene expression and laterality data were downloaded from TCGA-Xena Functional Genomics Explorer. GSEA was used to compare L-R tumors and identify gene sets with significant differences. Leading-edge analysis identified associated gene signatures.
chunks.chunk_summary: Public datasets from HGNC and TCGA were used for bioinformatic analysis, including GSEA and leading-edge analysis.
chunks.authors: ["Sofia Maselli", "Sebastian Real", "Patrick McMillen", "Madeleine Oudin", "Michael Levin", "Maria Roque"]

chunks.text: Statistical comparisons were performed using GraphPad Prism. Student's t-tests were used to compare fluorescence ratios. Data were normalized to a depolarized state using high KCl. Correlation analyses used Spearman rank coefficient. ROC curves were used to calculate sensitivity/specificity. Survival rates were analyzed by Kaplan-Meier plots.
chunks.chunk_summary: Various statistical methods, including t-tests, Spearman correlation, ROC analysis, and Kaplan-Meier plots, were used to analyze the data.
chunks.authors: ["Sofia Maselli", "Sebastian Real", "Patrick McMillen", "Madeleine Oudin", "Michael Levin", "Maria Roque"]

chunks.text: This section lists the references cited throughout the paper, providing details on the publications used to support the research findings and discussion.
chunks.chunk_summary: The references section lists the sources cited in the paper.
chunks.authors: ["Sofia Maselli", "Sebastian Real", "Patrick McMillen", "Madeleine Oudin", "Michael Levin", "Maria Roque"]
